466B229118544D35B98C73CA334D3E45.description: Investigate artist collectives, alternative gallery environments, artist run centers, or studentrun art pop-up centers, and consider opportunities to volunteer in own community.

B01D4C30EE9A487790B6D2077E631005.description: Examine roles, responsibilities and personal and professional qualities needed to continue developing an ongoing visual art practice.

160A4B2E75F64D05A3888497222BEB43.description: Investigate educational qualifications required to pursue various post-secondary pathways and career options.

56BED4099B2148E8BC31DF0AD29744B8.description: Examine how visual art, and the other arts, contribute to personal and social wellbeing in communities.

CF751AE32D3A4B259C4DD718313EC461.description: Interview a prominent artist about his/her education and career path.

9C811A591FE44FED882FC197405A7046.description: Explore job shadowing, mentorship and collaborative project opportunities in own communities.

B24BC736BF3D467DA20D3B5166155625.description: Investigate various funding (e.g., scholarships) and grant opportunities for continuing visual art practice including professional development for emerging and professional artists.

C924AD11B00D4CBFBA15C9FAB44AD071.description: Research formal and informal education opportunities and career paths taken by various local, Canadian and international visual artists (e.g., mentorships, professional associations, community workshops, Indigenous art-making and teaching practices, post-secondary education opportunities).

15CE1171588E4B908F60946A59C3C880.description: Investigate opportunities in arts communities and visual art-related practices and careers in Saskatchewan, Canada and the world.

A07F4B7756C349D4830E15EBD7743DFF.description: Examine the work of artists who incorporate and infuse traditional art forms with contemporary work (e.g., street art, mixed media assemblages, traditional beading patterns used in large scale paintings, historical references in contemporary clothing designs, combining text and images).

63B4536CFF484EECB5381602ECE1C1C6.description: Examine aspects of culture and history to determine how artists have impacted art historical and social norms and constructs (e.g., participatory arts expressions, social constructs of gender).

25EFE3F3C6D247CBA391A71029C93D06.description: Create art works and corresponding documentation to demonstrate an artistic technique and/or materials used in a work of art from a specific time in history (e.g., 1930s linocuts, Greek clay coiling, Renaissance egg tempera painting).

8D677AA5C4BD4AD7B00B1271B7F01D46.description: Respond to artistic and interactive presentations that utilize creative technologies (e.g., film and photo documentaries, movement-activated sculptures, interactive installations, performance art).

62049B083E3341E98CA2B5887E6177F7.description: Research a variety of sources (e.g., websites, galleries, communication media) to observe how artists incorporate and manipulate media, form and content in interdisciplinary work.

97419B2974204710837F24C722806474.description: Investigate how artists from around the world incorporate and manipulate media, form and content in interdisciplinary work.

83E56A3C30374ADA983B31BFBAFF5C35.description: Examine the work of artists whose art communicates personal experiences with human rights issues (e.g., newcomer artists).

BE784043A818402DA2C7E0FADE57CF04.description: Conduct an overview of treaties (e.g., treaty education outcome HC11 - evaluate specific treaties that have been, or currently are, in place globally to determine their effectiveness; and, outcome SI11 - analyze how the unfulfilled aspects of treaties, with international indigenous people, have resulted in inequities) and related human rights issues globally (e.g., Maori, Mapoon, South American, South Africa), and examine the work of Indigenous artists from those regions.

6266A4B09A8F45D5A785A7BA4E4A8803.description: Research and discuss art works that comment on the effects of colonization in Saskatchewan and around the world.

ABAAA1CBEC2F4203B210C6CEDF99E5EA.description: Conduct an inquiry into how art has helped to sustain the cultures of Saskatchewan First Nations and Métis and other Indigenous peoples of the world.

666C3DA7F3EE45A28EAA1E6ED07A8D9F.description: Explore and describe connections between art works that express social commentary concerning peoples from around the world (e.g., art works that comment on issues such as Indigenous health, racism, self-determination, environmental degradation).

E6C0CFC0E40F4173AF333340F03F9BD0.description: Investigate art works from around the world that address the human rights of Indigenous and various cultures.

8116CA64804D49849CC89CCF0BE9D4C6.description: Cultural/Historical (CH) Goal: Students will investigate the content and aesthetics of the arts within cultural, historical, and contemporary contexts, and understand the connection between the arts and the human experience.

861C047D24ED4B27BB17BDF2ED87FA4B.description: Reflect on and analyze the intentions, development and interpretations of own and peers’ art works in relation to broader regional, national or international contexts.

B0CBFC0F607649F7A4E40AA902D2556A.description: Apply assessment criteria to evaluate artistic merit of works of art.

8A3A8858B902444AAB00AB3577AF645F.description: Collaborate with peers to develop criteria for critiques.

A7A7A3AC1312420C8DB14F7EA162C889.description: Research and discuss how artists used media in a particular school/movement for specific intent.

32360A4F66D14B578583E157DE25191D.description: Discuss how objects and visual images can imply a multiplicity of meanings.

B885A858AE9B4D85B2450E9554668461.description: Demonstrate critical thinking during assessment of how the art material influences meaning of the work.

4AE010451B1B4F5583A741CED36F8386.description: Review works in progress to promote further development and refinement of own work.

EA02428220944B7788359D0806E19E46.description: Reflect on, and critically respond to, self and peer art works in progress to enhance ideas and convey meaning.

72707AABA5C24154B8756F5385B747F5.description: Support opinions for interpretation of ideas, symbols and images based on research and contexts in which the work was created.

B98055F94541448FB9C1331BD13903BC.description: Describe styles, techniques, themes, media, subjects and motifs that have become identified with groups of artists, historical periods and cultures.

B27FFBC5C3F24F56BB9EAD23C88D5A1F.description: Compare traditional and contemporary art works from a variety of places and cultures and discuss how ideas, values or beliefs are expressed and may change over time.

D16AF0ED87D14DE8A9CB7E5790B17B6C.description: Determine historical, social and environmental factors that may have influenced the production of art works and describe own interpretations and understanding of the works.

467F8488B1454D619EB93BA9E5893F49.description: Examine how art can be used as a powerful tool to promote ideas, political ideals, propaganda, perspectives and challenge misconceptions.

07F099D894D54713A111A94B9D7B1F17.description: Demonstrate understanding of the role of audience or consumer in various art making approaches and presentation environments (e.g., fine art galleries, public art spaces, interactive media, installations).

C53BBE629D9B471BB40B35E0C1BFECA7.description: Analyze art work and describe possible intention of the artist when interpreting meanings (e.g., Is the artist interested in formal concerns or, for example, prompting associations, social criticism, philosophical commentary, storytelling, making interdisciplinary connections?).

278F2A2AAF4C4567A168BE80185C6012.description: Examine how historical events (e.g., making traditional art practices illegal) and Eurocentric models of fine art (e.g., art vs craft) marginalized groups of artists (e.g., women, First Nations artists, Australian Indigenous artists, gender and sexually diverse artists).

AEAFF5B101284887981289ED12A4D392.description: Respond critically and creatively to art works from a variety of art historical movements and global cultural contexts.

56A1C7689B3646F18A517D81108735DE.description: Analyze factors (e.g., inspiration, technology, culture, environment, events, government policies) that influence art-making practices around the world, past and present.

B498F9C7E253405692D87183B269E4E1.description: Demonstrate understanding of the language of art and terminology when writing or discussing art works, recognizing historical contexts and respecting cultural practices.

F677BD261C534BB6B0FBDC496F741059.description: Discuss the use and impact, in various forms of visual art, of image development strategies

A82191CFA47942F8A8B194F694F47843.description: Draw on experience and expertise of students and/or community members to increase understanding of criteria used when responding to the diversity of art forms and artistic practices (e.g., beading, tattooing, clothing design, interactive sculpture).

3E3651B4539F488FAF5169099E3E5C74.description: Collaborate with peers to co-construct assessment criteria (e.g., technical skills, compositional qualities, use of images) for reflection on the development and resolution of own work, and identify what will be used as evidence of learning (e.g., journals, sketchbooks, artist’s statements, video documentation, critiques, portfolios).

BDD6568048614B6498D2C5DE0629720B.description: Identify criteria that are most appropriate to a particular form or style of art and apply when critiquing (e.g., architecture, designed object, cultural artifact, contemporary urban street art, comic, controversial public art).

5F00B957DB24443DB6153FFE337DAE41.description: Generate questions and conduct an inquiry into factors that influence judgements about the aesthetic quality or economic value of various forms of art (e.g., What is art? Who decides which art is good? Are there objective criteria for evaluating art? What factors influence the price of works of art? How does the art market work?).

ED7461A58939405E8792C1F7CC3F3992.description: Identify and analyse criteria for critiquing and valuing various forms of visual art.

D5CB66C2053542849AF8A656950EF0F5.description: Critical/Responsive (CR) Goal: Students will respond to artistic expressions of Saskatchewan, Canadian, and International artists using critical thinking, research, creativity, and collaborative inquiry.

639EF38CCDAD461681D7463A83578B85.description: Respond to the work of national and/or international artists (e.g., visit galleries, virtual tours, online resources) and consider how the ideas and/or media examined might influence own work and artistic growth.

8F802A2456844A7980B0CAA8E5CBCC7D.description: Use an artistic style in an original way (e.g., imagine the artist’s next work with own interpretation)

A5E7EAF0A8FD4779995F91FEE5921213.description: Examine artistic styles and use of image development strategies as references for own work.

A9EAF3E03449464FAF5709ACE6CFF7D4.description: Create an art work based on individual or collaborative inquiry, including for example: generating questions for inquiry about the work of national or international artists (e.g., How do art works reflect a sense of place?), comparing and contrasting the work of selected artists, researching and viewing works of recognized national or international artists, experimenting with techniques and media used by the artists, documenting the inquiry (e.g., portfolios, sketches, visual journals, notes, digital photos) and describing own decision-making and problem-solving processes, and reflecting on the effectiveness of choices made.

2794A2EBC492437997A65C302970DEBA.description: Propose topics, identify big ideas, generate questions for inquiry, create a plan to guide the inquiry and document the creative process.

AF69215033D64C1BA390475C5B32F08B.description: Use inquiry to create a work of art inspired by the work of national and/or international artists.

7D2464EA4AB943238DF72BDAE4EE8503.description: Examine how visual art, and the other arts, contribute to personal and social wellbeing in communities.

96423FB935E9424F9B82336CC02D472F.description: Follow Workplace Hazardous Material Information System (WHMIS) and art classroom safety guidelines.

72D5353D13BC4B6A9B9FCBC86BF724C6.description: Research a controversial topic (e.g., climate change, the plight of asylum seekers, equity for individuals and couples who are gender and sexually diverse, political activism) from the perspective of opposing or diverse worldviews (e.g., philosophical, spiritual, gender, feminist, cultural) and respond to the same topic through own art work.

E99C5987551140768CFCB250D91AC704.description: Examine symbolism incorporated in art works from diverse worldviews and consider the use of symbolism in own work.

32863CBDB75E43DA8D89F3BB2D730D6A.description: Express personal and cultural identity through own work and the exploration of various artistic practices (e.g., printmaking, installation, photography).

FFAB77558EDB4581AAE8C2E8CEB89D1D.description: Research art works that reflect diverse worldviews (e.g., Indigenous, Western, religious, francophone, feminist, newcomer, traditional, cultural) and apply learning to own work.

E9BAACF6A68449EB96A238610B70A234.description: Create art works, using various practices (e.g., drawing, painting, crafting, printmaking, digital technologies, sculpture, installation), that respond to diverse worldviews.

29FBAF8331404F3F88E35FF4AA9299BB.description: Examine respectful ways of using sources of inspiration including issues of appropriation (e.g., What are the dynamics that make “borrowing” ideas appropriate or not?).

3250FAEF3C494774AEAFEFF9FA3E432F.description: Explore Métis history, stories, traditions and visual art imagery as a way of opening a path to students’ using their own community contexts as inspiration for art making.

6227F3791FE34D4E9D307925466BDA85.description: Engage with Indigenous and non-Indigenous artists to discuss sources of inspiration and art practices, and apply new knowledge to own work.

9BD80ABE285540B1A2F3FD29378CDF2A.description: Engage with First Nations and Métis Elders, Knowledge Keepers, community leaders and artists to examine sources of inspiration for traditional cultural and contemporary visual art practices (e.g., gifting of knowledge, protocols concerning use of images, issues of appropriation).

FAAABAEE811E499DA46DD1119E43EB30.description: Explore personal values, experiences, beliefs and ways of knowing as inspiration for own art work.

83B3E1AFC4AA402E87EE30595630F4B4.description: Follow Workplace Hazardous Material Information System (WHMIS) and art classroom safety guidelines.

5ED5FBE046434933BBDF0C18865A387B.description: Work in unfamiliar styles and techniques considering how to develop a personal style or voice.

27AFAA5EF7D34D5CAABB29E932D48578.description: Conduct a hands-on inquiry into various visual art practices to inform own practice.

3AF165303C164E70A81D9F9942524129.description: Solve a selected visual art challenge or problem (e.g., How do artists explore and develop an idea?) using one or more visual art practices.

D8BF9FD19119487880F89B6C5FE7890D.description: Document ideas using methods such as sketchbooks, thumbnail sketches, photographs or video.

A3898593ADF14E55A0CB9FDDDE2C63C4.description: Study and investigate ideas using a variety of art-making practices.

F4D403DC05094F099D3854088B88F263.description: Individually or collectively generate ideas for art making, drawing on various sources of inspiration.

5CF4A04CC25A4DEC860C0E3C11387297.description: Experiment with a variety of visual art practices (e.g., drawing, painting, crafting, printmaking, digital technologies, sculpture) to explore ideas derived from various sources of inspiration including perspectives of First Nations and Métis people in Saskatchewan.

0ABE501F451844A7B939574029403067.description: Examine the practice of art-making in supporting one’s mental health and wellness.

F674D2AE6B6142E3B9244DBF9279CAEE.description: Follow Workplace Hazardous Material Information System (WHMIS) and art classroom safety guidelines.

77B4956CE9B44045ABF03D1BCB689336.description: Demonstrate risk taking through experimentation with new ideas, unfamiliar media and image development strategies.

F3BD5BF5452147A883DF593BF10E9840.description: Portray an idea in different ways using a variety of media, image development strategies and current technologies.

7BF7B59D956B4EF18713E6B9C5B4122F.description: Initiate and develop ideas from a variety of sources of inspiration (e.g., treaties, sustainability, fiction, music, YouTube, other artists’ artistic styles).

FAFC2E44AD9640BA8538A07012833207.description: Investigate a variety of contexts, perspectives, visual art media, forms and techniques to communicate ideas visually.

69034D834F4846039B397C251F383AB3.description: Examine and explore how design and composition in own art work impacts meaning, considering, for example: Elements of Art, Principles pf Design and Sample Image Development Strategies

7DFBBBBE0EF841639D1559248A84009C.description: Engage in artistic risk-taking with ideas, media and image development strategies to achieve meaning.

1538A6E3B667406894D979A16FBE093D.description: Creative/Productive (CP) Goal: Students will inquire, create, and communicate through dance, drama, music and visual art.
